docs.lead_paragraph: At some point, you have to start indulging in the pleasures of the present.

headline.main: Too Young to Die, Too Old to Worry
headline.print_headline: Too Young to Die, Too Old to Worry

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Jason Karlawish reflects on decision by singer Leonard Cohen to resume smoking again at the age of 80; contends decision raises question of when one should set aside life lived for future and instead embrace pleasures of the present.
docs.snippet: At some point, you have to start indulging in the pleasures of the present.

docs.lead_paragraph: Paleo has charged toward the mainstream, not just as a hugely popular diet, but also as a cave-man-inspired lifestyle that has spawned a fast-growing industry.

headline.main: The Paleo Lifestyle: The Way, Way, Way Back

docs.abstract: Paleo diet has charged toward the mainstream as a cave-man-inspired lifestyle that has spawned a fast-growing industry; there are now magazines, conferences, vacation retreats and many products dedicated to the Paleo lifestyle.
docs.snippet: Paleo has charged toward the mainstream, not just as a hugely popular diet, but also as a cave-man-inspired lifestyle that has spawned a fast-growing industry.

docs.abstract: He wanted his body given to a medical school or research organization. It wasn’t that simple.
docs.snippet: He wanted his body given to a medical school or research organization. It wasn’t that simple.

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. government will set up a task force and presidential advisory council to tackle the growing threat of antibiotic resistance, setting a Feb. 15 deadline for it to outline specific steps, White House advisers said on Thursday.

headline.main: White House Calls for Task Force to Tackle Antibiotic-Resistant Bugs
headline.print_headline: White House Calls for Task Force to Tackle Antibiotic-Resistant Bugs

docs.snippet: The U.S. government will set up a task force and presidential advisory council to tackle the growing threat of antibiotic resistance, setting a Feb. 15 deadline for it to outline specific steps, White House advisers said on Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: In her free time Isha Turay, an 18-year-old Sierra Leonean student, sells vegetables on Malama Thomas Street in the heart of the bustling capital, Freetown, so that she and her siblings can eat.

headline.main: Fear and Hope as Sierra Leone Braces for Three-Day Ebola Lockdown
headline.print_headline: Fear and Hope as Sierra Leone Braces for Three-Day Ebola Lockdown

docs.snippet: In her free time Isha Turay, an 18-year-old Sierra Leonean student, sells vegetables on Malama Thomas Street in the heart of the bustling capital, Freetown, so that she and her siblings can eat.

docs.lead_paragraph: The move by the secretary-general, Ban Ki-moon, signaled his concern with the response so far and the limitations of the World Health Organization’s ability to handle it alone.

headline.main: U.N. Leader Plans Stronger Presence in Ebola Zone
headline.print_headline: U.N. Leader Plans Stronger Presence in Ebola Zone

docs.abstract: United Nations Sec Gen Ban Ki-moon says he plans to establish a new on-the-ground mission in West Africa to coordinate the struggle against Ebola.
docs.snippet: The move by the secretary-general, Ban Ki-moon, signaled his concern with the response so far and the limitations of the World Health Organization’s ability to handle it alone.

byline.original: By SOMINI SENGUPTA, RICK GLADSTONE and SHERI FINK

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama, warning that the disease could take hundreds of thousands of lives, called on other nations to help the United States as it leads the fight.

headline.main: Obama Presses Leaders to Speed Ebola Response
headline.print_headline: Obama Pressing Leaders to Speed Ebola Response

docs.abstract: Pres Obama challenges world powers to accelerate global response to Ebola outbreak ravaging West Africa; warns that unless health care workers, medical equipment and treatment centers are swiftly deployed, disease could take hundreds of thousands of lives.
docs.snippet: President Obama, warning that the disease could take hundreds of thousands of lives, called on other nations to help the United States as it leads the fight.

byline.contributor: Helene Cooper reported from Atlanta, and Sheri Fink from New York. Reporting was contributed by Denise Grady and Donald G. McNeil Jr. from New York; Nick Cumming-Bruce from Geneva; Norimitsu Onishi from Monrovia, Liberia; Ashley Parker from Washington; and Somini Sengupta from the United Nations.
byline.original: By HELENE COOPER and SHERI FINK

docs.lead_paragraph: Florida patients with epilepsy and other diseases hoping to gain limited access to medical marijuana may have to keep waiting as the state's largest nursery is contesting newly developed rules needed to roll out a special strain of cannabis.

headline.main: Dispute Could Delay Florida Rollout of Limited Medical Marijuana
headline.print_headline: Dispute Could Delay Florida Rollout of Limited Medical Marijuana

docs.snippet: Florida patients with epilepsy and other diseases hoping to gain limited access to medical marijuana may have to keep waiting as the state's largest nursery is contesting newly developed rules needed to roll out a special strain of cannabis.

docs.lead_paragraph: Though enthusiasm for potential advances in disease and injury treatments often outstrips the science, thousands of clinical trials are now underway to figure out how to best use stem cells.

headline.seo: Stem Cells: Plenty of Hope, but Halting Progress
headline.main: The Trials of Stem Cell Therapy
headline.print_headline: The Trials of Stem Cell Therapy

docs.abstract: Experimental stem cell procedures, once talked about but not put into practice, are starting to be used in trial settings; as many as 4,500 clinical trials involving stem cells are under way in United States to treat patients with conditions such as heart disease, blindness, Parkinson's and spinal cord injury; enthusiasm for such procedures, however, sometimes outstrips supporting science.
docs.snippet: Though enthusiasm for potential advances in disease and injury treatments often outstrips the science, thousands of clinical trials are now underway to figure out how to best use stem cells.

docs.lead_paragraph: Of the 22 industrial hog farm workers tested in a new study, 10 carried antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria in their noses for up to four days, raising public health questions.
docs.abstract: Study in journal Occupational and Environmental Medicine finds that workers in industrial hog farms may continue to carry antibiotic-resistant bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus, over several days, raising new questions for public health officials struggling to contain spread of such pathogens.
docs.snippet: Of the 22 industrial hog farm workers tested in a new study, 10 carried antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria in their noses for up to four days, raising public health questions.
